summary.p: [1] Blasius and [Luzi Heim] received Bullinger's letter [not received] through merchants along with Emperor Charles V's proposition for the [Augsburg] Diet. They forwarded Bullinger's letter intended for [Francesco] Negri [not received] to him.

[2] Last week, Blasius was in Chiavenna as well as in the Valtellina towns of Traona and Caspano. There, a successor was chosen for the preacher [...] expelled from Caspano, namely the noble Doctor Raphael Paravicini. This will trouble the devil once again! In Chiavenna, there is a serious dispute between Agostino Mainardi and Camillo Renato regarding the sacraments. While Mainardi holds the view that the sacraments confirm God's covenants, Renato is against it. Since both have a truly Italian temperament, there will be much trouble!

[3] Verified news came from Italy regarding the Emperor. His troops cunningly and treacherously took Parma and Piacenza. Duke Pier Luigi Farnese was stabbed [in Piacenza] and thrown out of the castle. [Galeotto II. Pico della] Mirandola arrived [to help] an hour and a half too late and withdrew with his mercenaries back to Mirandola.

div.p: Grace and peace from the Lord, etc. We received your letter along with the Emperor's proposition from merchants and forwarded the letter intended for Negri, etc.

Last week, I was in Chiavenna and in the Valtellina towns of Traona and Caspano, where another minister was appointed in place of the expelled one; a doctor and nobleman they chose, named Dr. Raphael Paravicini. Without a doubt, Satan will once again cause trouble, etc. In Chiavenna, I found a harmful contention between Agostino and Camillo regarding the sacraments: Agostino wants the sacraments, which confirm God's covenants; Camillo opposes it. I am concerned it will serve as a great scandal, as they are truly Italian temperaments, etc.

From Italy, certain news has arrived here concerning the Emperor, how his troops cunningly and treacherously took Parma and Piacenza, stabbed Pier Luigi Farnese, and threw him out of the castle. Mirandola arrived an hour and a half too late. He had to retreat with his troops back to Mirandola, etc.
Farewell, most distinguished man, through the Lord God, who may deign to preserve you for us and His church for a long time. Amen. In haste, Chur, 20th September, 1547.
To the most esteemed man in prudence, learning, and true piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most steadfast bishop of the Zurich church, his most revered lord.
